Only permissible with People of the Book (Jews and Christians) but not others

explanation: Having iftar with non-Muslims is permissible if there is a shar'i reason for doing so, such as calling them to the true religion or softening their hearts toward Islam. This can happen at communal iftar tables in some countries. The key is having a legitimate Islamic purpose, not merely social interaction.

questionText: What is the correct way to use the supplication of Dhu'n-Noon (Yunus) when calling upon Allah?

options.text: Say the complete dhikr 'La ilaha illa anta subhanaka inni kuntu min adh-dhalimin' then mention your specific need afterward
Simply intend your need while reciting the dhikr without stating the need explicitly
Recite only 'La ilaha illa anta' and that is sufficient for any need
The supplication should only be used when in extreme distress like Yunus was

explanation: The Prophet explained that no Muslim calls upon Allah with this supplication for anything but Allah will answer him. The proper method is to recite the complete dhikr of Dhu'n-Noon ('La ilaha illa anta subhanaka inni kuntu min adh-dhalimin') then mention your specific need after it. This follows the Prophetic teaching about how to use this powerful supplication.

questionText: Who is credited with planting the seed of Shi'ism according to classical and contemporary scholars?

options.text: The Jew Abdullah ibn Saba' at the end of Uthmaan's caliphate, which is even admitted in Shi'ah books themselves
Ali ibn Abi Talib after the murder of Uthmaan
The Umayyad dynasty to divide the Muslim community
Persian scholars during the Abbasid caliphate

explanation: Many classical and contemporary scholars hold that Shi'ism began with the murder of Uthmaan, planted by the Jew Abdullah ibn Saba' at the end of Uthmaan's caliphate. This is admitted in Shi'ah books like al-Maqaalaat wa'l-Firaq by al-Qummi and Firaq ash-Shi'ah by an-Nawbakhti. Ibn Saba' was an extreme heretic who led the Saba'iyyah sect.

questionText: What is the ruling on offering the funeral prayer for someone who died while offering sacrifices to the jinn?

options.text: It is not permissible to pray over him, wash him, shroud him, or bury him with Muslims because he is a mushrik
The funeral prayer can be offered but he cannot be buried in a Muslim cemetery
It is permissible if he repented before death
Only the burial is forbidden, but washing and shrouding are allowed

explanation: It is not permissible to offer the funeral prayer over him, wash him, shroud him, or bury him with Muslims because he is a mushrik. The same applies to one who prays to the jinn, awliya' (saints), or occupants of graves, or offers sacrifices to them.

questionText: What is the Islamic ruling on using Chinese calendar tables to determine the sex of a foetus?

options.text: They are a kind of soothsaying and charlatanry, as the baby's gender is knowledge of the absolute unseen known only to Allah
They are permissible as long as used only after conception, not for planning
They are permissible based on modern Chinese medical knowledge
They are disliked (makruh) but not completely forbidden

explanation: These tables are soothsaying and charlatanry with no medical basis. Finding out the foetus's sex before conception is knowledge of the absolute unseen which only Allah knows. The tables have connections to Buddhism, astrology, and horoscopes, and have been proven false on many occasions.

questionText: What is the difference between the names and attributes of Allah?

options.text: Names refer to two things (Allah Himself and an attribute), while attributes refer to one thing (the quality itself)
Names are mentioned in the Quran while attributes come from hadith only
Attributes describe Allah's essence while names describe His actions
There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable

explanation: Allah's names refer to both Allah Himself and one of His perfect attributes (like al-'Aleem refers to Allah and His knowledge), so names refer to two things. Attributes refer to one thing only. It was also said that the name includes the attribute and the attribute implies the name.

questionText: What is the ruling on surrogacy (renting wombs) where an egg is fertilized and implanted in another woman's womb?

options.text: It is haram because Allah commands guarding chastity except with wives or slaves, and it leads to confusion of lineage
It is permissible if the surrogate is a close relative
It is permissible with the consent of all parties involved
It is permissible only in cases of medical necessity

explanation: Shaykh al-Jibrin stated this is haram primarily because Allah commands us to guard our chastity except with wives or slaves. Womb-renting leads to confusion of lineage, disputes over who the mother is, and was never permitted by previous scholars despite the means existing. It is a Western innovation.

questionText: What is the connection between a person's provision (rizq) and their death according to Islamic teaching?

options.text: A person's lifespan itself is a type of provision, and when it ends, the person dies—provision ends when lifespan ends
Death occurs when a person's wealth and material provision completely run out
Provision determines lifespan, so those with more wealth live longer
They are unrelated—provision is worldly sustenance while death is determined separately

explanation: The individual's lifespan is how long he remains in this world, and it is a type of provision (rizq) which, when it comes to an end, the individual dies. His lifespan is his allotted period, and his appointed time of death is when that period ends. Whatever Allah decreed of provision ends when lifespan ends.

questionText: What is the best way to divide the udhiyah (sacrifice) meat according to Islamic teaching?

options.text: Eat one-third, give one-third as gifts to the rich and poor, and give one-third in charity
Give all of it in charity without eating any
Eat half and give half in charity only
Distribute it equally in quarters among family, friends, neighbors, and the poor

explanation: It is prescribed to eat some, give some as gifts, and give some in charity. Scholars differed on amounts, but the best way is one-third each. The Prophet said 'Eat some, give some to others and store some.' Giving to others includes both gifts to the rich and charity to the poor.

questionText: When should a Muslim have suhoor (pre-dawn meal) during Ramadan according to the suggested program?

options.text: Delay suhoor until the latest possible time of the night before Fajr prayer
Eat suhoor immediately after Isha prayer
Have suhoor at midnight to allow proper digestion
Eat suhoor one hour after starting the fast

explanation: The suggested Ramadan program recommends that the Muslim start his day with suhoor before Fajr prayer, and it is better to delay suhoor until the latest possible time of the night. Then he gets ready for Fajr prayer before the adhan.

questionText: Is writing down a marriage contract required for its validity in Islam?

options.text: No, the contract can be made verbally through offer and acceptance, though writing serves as good documentation
Yes, all marriage contracts must be written to be valid
Writing is required only for marriages involving non-Arabs
Verbal contracts are valid only if witnessed by a scholar

explanation: Writing is not a condition for validity of the marriage contract. It may be made verbally through offer by the guardian ("I marry my daughter to you") and acceptance by the groom ("I accept"). Writing serves to document and confirm the contract, which is good especially nowadays.

questionText: If a man divorces his wife before consummating the marriage, what type of divorce is it according to scholarly consensus?

options.text: It is an irrevocable divorce, and she cannot return to him except with a new marriage contract fulfilling all conditions
It is a revocable divorce and he can take her back during the 'iddah period
The divorce is not valid before consummation according to consensus
She can return with his verbal declaration only, without a new contract

explanation: Ibn Qudaamah stated that scholars are unanimously agreed that a woman with whom marriage has not been consummated is irrevocably divorced with one talaaq. The one who divorced her cannot take her back because taking back occurs during 'iddah, and there is no 'iddah before consummation per Quran 33:40.

questionText: If husbands are detained and wives cannot reach them during Ramadan, who is responsible for paying Zakat al-Fitr?

options.text: The husband remains obligated and makes it up when able; wives should pay for themselves if able, otherwise excused
Zakat al-Fitr is waived entirely in such situations
The wife's family must pay on behalf of both spouses
The wife must pay for herself and her husband regardless of ability

explanation: Zakat al-fitr is obligatory upon the head of household. If unable to pay, Allah excuses him and he makes it up later. Wives able to pay should do so for themselves. If unable, they're excused per 'Allah burdens not a person beyond his scope' (al-Baqarah 2:286).

questionText: Does man have free will and choice according to Islamic teaching?

options.text: Yes, the accountable individual has ability and freedom to choose to believe or disbelieve, which is why he is held accountable
No, everything is predetermined and man has no choice in his actions
Humans have free will but jinn do not
Free will exists only for major decisions, not daily actions

explanation: The accountable individual has ability and freedom to choose, whether human or jinni. Through this he may believe or disbelieve, obey or disobey, as Allah says 'whoever wills - let him believe; and whoever wills - let him disbelieve' (Al-Kahf 18:29). Because he is capable, he will be requited for his deeds.
tags: Belief in the Divine Will and Decree

questionText: If a person with urinary incontinence renews wudu before the prayer time ends, must he wash his private parts again?

options.text: No, he does not have to wash private parts when renewing wudu before the prayer time ends, only when a new prayer time begins
Yes, he must wash private parts every time he renews wudu regardless of time
He must wash private parts only if more than 30 minutes have passed
Washing is required only for obligatory prayers, not naafil

explanation: If one continually breaking wudu renews it before prayer time is over, he doesn't have to wash private parts because he has wudu according to the ruling. But when the time for one prayer ends, he must wash private parts and do wudu again. The Prophet told Fatimah bint Abi Hubaysh to 'do wudu for each prayer until that time comes.'
tags: Cleaning oneself after defecating or urinating

questionText: What are the essential things a Muslim should know when dealing with a book of knowledge?

options.text: Know the book's subject, its terminology, and the author's style and phrases used
Only memorize the content without worrying about context or terminology
Focus solely on the author's biography and credentials
Read it multiple times without concerning yourself with specialized terms

explanation: Dealing with a book involves: 1) Knowing the subject so he can benefit and specialize, 2) Knowing its terminology to save time (like what 'agreed upon' means varies by author), 3) Knowing the author's style and phrases, which become familiar with repeated reading.

questionText: If a wound is covered with a bandage, what should be done during wudu?

options.text: Wash the healthy parts, then wet the hand with water and wipe over the dressing—no tayammum needed
Do complete tayammum instead of wudu
Skip washing that limb entirely and do tayammum for it
Remove the bandage, wash the wound, then reapply the bandage

explanation: If a wound is covered with dressing or bandage, wash the healthy parts then wet your hand with water and wipe over the dressing. If you do this, you don't need tayammum. This is the authentic view from Ibn Umar according to al-Bayhaqi.

questionText: What is the ruling on making sweets or cakes in the shape of animate beings?

options.text: It is not permissible because of the general meaning of hadiths prohibiting making images—every image maker will be in Hell
It is permissible since they are edible and will be consumed
It is permissible if made for children only
It is makruh (disliked) but not haram

explanation: It is not permissible to make sweets or cakes in the shape of animate beings because of the general meaning of hadiths prohibiting images. The Prophet said 'Every image maker will be in Hell, and for every image that he made, a soul will be created which will punish him in Hell' (Muslim 2110).

questionText: What is the view on organizing communal iftaars specifically to encourage people to observe naafil fasts?

options.text: There is nothing wrong with it, but it is better not to do it because the Sahaabah did not do such a thing
It is highly recommended and should be done regularly
It is forbidden as an innovation in religion
It is obligatory when trying to revive the Sunnah of fasting

explanation: There is nothing wrong with organizing communal iftaars to encourage naafil fasting, but it is better not to do this because the Sahaabah did not do such a thing. If people can be encouraged through words, that is sufficient without doing it through deeds.

questionText: When is it not permissible to tell people about a cheaper source for a product someone else is promoting?

options.text: When you become certain the promoter has made a sale or someone has agreed on a price with him
It is never permissible to interfere in someone else's business dealings
Only if you are related to the person promoting the product
It is always permissible to inform people of cheaper alternatives

explanation: There is nothing wrong with telling people about cheaper prices unless you become certain that the one promoting the product has already made a sale or someone has negotiated and agreed on a price. In that case, it is prohibited to undersell your brother, as mentioned in the hadith narrated by al-Bukhari (2139) and Muslim (1412).

questionText: For Muslims who are not specialists in Islamic sciences, what should they primarily adhere to?

options.text: The Qur'an and saheeh Sunnah, for in them is guidance and light and protection from error
Strictly follow one madhhab without ever considering other views
The opinions of contemporary scholars only
Their own personal reasoning and interpretation

explanation: The advice for all Muslims who are not specialists in Islamic sciences is to adhere to the straight path Allah has enjoined: the Qur'an and saheeh Sunnah, for in them is guidance and light, and protection from error and misguidance.

questionText: If someone wakes at Fajr time intending to pray after a short sleep but oversleeps past the prayer time, what is the ruling?

options.text: Pray immediately upon waking and be determined not to let it happen again—Allah forgives this mistake
This person has committed kufr according to all scholars
The prayer is permanently invalid and cannot be made up
Fast for three days as expiation before praying

explanation: If you woke at Fajr time with intention to wake after a short while but didn't wake until the time was over, pray straight away and be determined to get up in future. Don't let Shaytaan play with you. However, if you intended not to pray until after the time, some scholars consider this kufr.

questionText: Until what age is a child whose father has died considered an orphan in Islamic law?

options.text: Until age fifteen or earlier if signs of puberty appear (ejaculation, pubic hair growth, or menstruation for females)
Until age eighteen regardless of physical maturity
Until age twenty-one or when married
Until they finish their education

explanation: A child is regarded as an orphan until reaching puberty, i.e., age fifteen or earlier if signs of puberty appear. These signs are: emission of gushing water during intercourse or wet-dream, growth of coarse hair around private parts, and in females, menstruation (al-Mughni by Ibn Qudaamah, 6/591).
tags: Sponsoring orphans and taking them into one's care

questionText: What did the Prophet (peace be upon him) say about a righteous son's benefit to his deceased parent?

options.text: A righteous son who will pray for him is among three things that continue benefiting after death, along with ongoing charity and beneficial knowledge
A righteous son's deeds are automatically transferred to the parent's record
Only the son's first prayer after the parent's death benefits them
The son must perform Hajj on behalf of the parent for any benefit

explanation: The Prophet said: 'When the son of Adam dies, all his good deeds come to an end, apart from three: sadaqah jariyah (ongoing charity), beneficial knowledge, and a righteous son who will pray for him' (Muslim, 1631). This shows a righteous son's prayers continue benefiting the deceased parent.

questionText: What is the basic Islamic principle regarding the relationship between spouses?

options.text: It should be based on each treating the other with kindness, as Allah says 'Live with them in accordance with what is fair and kind'
The husband has absolute authority and the wife must obey without question
Each spouse should maintain complete independence from the other
The wife's primary duty is housework while the husband provides income

explanation: The basic Islamic principle for spousal relationships is that it should be based on each treating the other with kindness, as Allah says 'Live with them in accordance with what is fair and kind' (an-Nisa 4:19). Each spouse must treat the other with kindness and good companionship, refraining from harm.

questionText: What defines the boundaries of Mina during Hajj, and can these boundaries be expanded through ijtihad?

options.text: Boundaries are from Waadi Muhassir to Jamrat al-'Aqabah, clearly defined by the Lawgiver with no room for ijtihad
Boundaries can be expanded based on modern needs and scholarly consensus
Any area within 5 kilometers of the original Mina counts as valid
Boundaries are flexible and determined by each country's Hajj authorities

explanation: The places and times of Hajj are clearly defined by the Lawgiver with no room for ijtihad. The boundaries of Mina are from Waadi Muhassir to Jamrat al-'Aqabah. The Messenger explained this in the Farewell Pilgrimage saying 'Learn from me your rituals of Hajj.' If one cannot get a spot within Mina, stay in the nearest place with no penalty.

questionText: What are the two main reservations about working as a doctor in a hotel where foreign guests dress indecently?

options.text: Foreigners are usually improperly dressed causing fitnah, and it involves helping disbelievers against Muslims or supporting tourism harming Muslims
The payment is likely to be in foreign currency which is haram, and working hours conflict with prayer times
Hotels serve alcohol and pork, and the doctor would be paid from these earnings
Medical privacy laws conflict with Islamic rulings, and insurance is involved

explanation: Two factors are subject to reservations: 1) These foreigners are usually improperly dressed, exposing the doctor to grave fitnah. 2) Such work may involve helping disbelievers against Muslims or supporting tourism that harms Muslim lands. The basic principle allows working as a doctor while adhering to Islamic guidelines.

questionText: When should sitting mutawarrikan (tawarruk) be done in prayer?

options.text: In the final rak'ah when the Prophet sat—he put his left foot forward, held the right upright, and sat on his behind
In every rak'ah after the second sajdah
Only during the first tashahhud in a four-rak'ah prayer
Only in Witr prayer, not in obligatory prayers

explanation: Sitting mutawarrikan is a proven Sunnah done in the final rak'ah. Al-Bukhari narrated from Abu Humayd describing the Prophet's prayer: 'When he sat in the final rak'ah, he put his left foot forward and held the other foot upright, and sat on his behind.'
tags: The second pillar of prayer: standing

questionText: What is meant by the Prophet's words 'Read the Quran, for it will come as an intercessor for its companions'?

options.text: 'Companions' means those who constantly and regularly read or recite it, whether from Mus-haf or by heart
Only those who have memorized the entire Quran qualify as 'companions'
'Companions' refers only to the Sahabah who lived with the Prophet
It means reading it once in your lifetime is sufficient for intercession

explanation: The command 'Iqra'u (read, recite)' refers to reading in general, from Mus-haf or by heart. 'Companions' means those who read it constantly and regularly—the companion is one who constantly stays with you. This indicates continuous, regular reading, not occasional.

questionText: What are the signs that indicate a male has reached puberty (age of accountability) in Islam?

options.text: Reaching age fifteen, growth of pubic hair, or emission of maniy with desire when awake or asleep
Reaching age thirteen, growth of armpit hair, or emission of madhiy
Reaching age eighteen, having a wet dream, or growing a beard
Reaching age sixteen or getting married, whichever comes first

explanation: Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymeen stated puberty is reached when one of three things occurs in males: 1) Reaching age fifteen, 2) Growth of pubic hair, 3) Emission of maniy with desire when awake or asleep. Emission of madhiy and armpit hair growth are NOT signs of puberty.

questionText: Does vomiting break the fast, and does the ruling differ based on how it occurred?

options.text: Deliberate vomiting breaks the fast and requires making up the day; involuntary vomiting does not affect the fast
All vomiting breaks the fast regardless of whether it was deliberate
Vomiting never breaks the fast under any circumstances
Only vomiting food breaks the fast; vomiting water or bile does not

explanation: The ruling depends on whether vomiting was deliberate or not. If a person vomits deliberately, this breaks the fast and he must make up that day. If he cannot help vomiting and vomits involuntarily, his fast is still valid and he doesn't have to do anything else.

questionText: What is the Islamic ruling on donating bone marrow according to the Islamic Fiqh Council?

options.text: It is permissible to take it from adults if it will not cause them any harm
It is completely forbidden under all circumstances
It is permissible only when donating to Muslims, not non-Muslims
It is permissible only from deceased donors, not living ones

explanation: The Islamic Fiqh Council stated it is permissible to take bone marrow from adults if that will not cause them harm. The Muslim will be rewarded if his intention is sincerely for Allah and he intends to do good to the recipient, whether Muslim or non-Muslim.

questionText: If someone's daughter reached puberty and had to stop her umrah due to sickness without completing it, what must she do?

options.text: Pay fidyah—a sheep to be slaughtered in Makkah and distributed among the poor living in the Haram
Nothing is required since sickness is a valid excuse
Perform umrah again the following year
Fast three days as expiation

explanation: If she had reached puberty when she stopped her ihram, she must pay fidyah—a sheep slaughtered in Makkah and distributed among the poor in the Haram, according to the majority of scholars. This applies to everyone stopped by sickness etc. from completing Hajj or Umrah when they didn't make a condition upon entering ihram.

questionText: How many phrases are in the first form of iqamah narrated from the Prophet?

options.text: Eleven phrases, including 'qad qamat il-salah' said twice
Seventeen phrases with all statements repeated
Seven phrases matching the adhan exactly
Thirteen phrases with 'Allahu akbar' said four times

explanation: The first form of iqamah has eleven phrases: Allahu akbar (2x), ash-hadu an la ilah ill-Allah, ash-hadu anna Muhammadan Rasul-Allah, hayya 'ala al-salah, hayya 'ala'l-falah, qad qamat il-salah (2x), Allahu akbar (2x). This is one of several authentic forms narrated from the Prophet.

questionText: After stoning the Jamaraat on the 13th of Dhu'l-Hijjah after the sun passes meridian, can the pilgrim leave immediately?

options.text: Yes, he may leave and doesn't have to stay in Mina until sunset because he has finished the act of worship
No, he must stay in Mina until sunset on the 13th
He can leave only if he stones before noon
He must stay one more night in Mina before leaving

explanation: Whoever stones the Jamaraat on the thirteenth after the sun passes meridian may leave without staying until sunset, because he has finished the act of worship. Allah says 'Then whoever hastens [his departure] in two days - there is no sin upon him' (al-Baqarah 2:203). The word 'yawm' (day) applies to daylight hours.

questionText: What is one of the essential conditions of marriage according to the hadith of Abu Hurayrah?

options.text: Consent of both parties—a virgin cannot be married until her consent is sought, and for her, silence is consent
The father's decision is final regardless of the daughter's consent
Only the groom's consent is required for the marriage to be valid
Verbal consent is required from virgins but not from previously-married women

explanation: The Prophet said 'A virgin cannot be married until her consent has been sought and a previously-married woman cannot be married until she has been consulted.' When asked what her consent is, he said 'If she remains silent' (al-Bukhari 5136, Muslim 1419). Consent is essential in marriage.

questionText: Why doesn't Islam specifically tell us to eat less red meat in the Quran?

options.text: The Quran is a book of guidance and law-giving, not a book of medicine or astronomy—it leads mankind from darkness to light
Red meat was not available during the Prophet's time
The Quran actually does forbid eating red meat in several verses
Medical knowledge about red meat's effects was unknown to Allah

explanation: The Quran is a book of guidance and law-giving, not a book of medicine or astronomy. Allah says '(This is) a Book which We have revealed unto you in order that you might lead mankind out of darkness (of disbelief) into light (of belief in the Oneness of Allah).' It is not expected to mention every detail about medicine, astronomy, plants or animals.

questionText: What is the development stage of a balut egg that is taken to market?

options.text: An egg incubated for 16-20 days (instead of the normal 28) with a real embryo and primitive skeleton
A freshly laid egg within the first 3 days
An egg that has completed the full 28-day development
An egg incubated for exactly 7 days with no visible embryo

explanation: Balut is an egg incubated for only 16-20 days (normal development takes 28 days), during which it develops a real embryo with primitive skeleton. At 16-20 days, it is ready for market where it will be boiled for customers.
tags: Forbidden kinds of food and drink

questionText: When should the groom lead his bride in praying two rak'ahs according to the hadith of Ibn Mas'ood?

options.text: When he goes in unto her (enters her private quarters), not immediately after the marriage contract
Immediately after the marriage contract is signed
During the walimah (wedding feast)
On the morning after the wedding night

explanation: The hadith of Ibn Mas'ood reports that the groom should lead his bride in praying two rak'ahs when he goes in unto her, not immediately after the marriage contract. One should pray two rak'ahs for istikhaarah before the marriage contract.

questionText: What is the ruling on interlacing one's fingers when heading towards the mosque for prayer?

options.text: It is makruh (disliked)—one should not interlace fingers when going to pray until one has prayed
It is completely forbidden and invalidates wudu
It is permissible at all times including when heading to the mosque
It is only forbidden inside the mosque, not while walking to it

explanation: This is part of mosque etiquette. Ka'b ibn 'Ujrah told someone not to interlace fingers when heading to the mosque, citing that the Prophet said 'When one of you does wudu and does it well, then goes out heading for the mosque' one should not interlace fingers until having prayed.

questionText: What should you do when eating meat and you don't know whether Allah's name was mentioned when slaughtering it?

options.text: Say the name of Allah yourself then eat, especially if the people who brought it are new in Islam
Refuse to eat the meat until you verify the slaughter method
Eat without saying anything since the responsibility is on the slaughterer
Give the meat to non-Muslims since it may not be halal

explanation: It was proven in Sahih al-Bukhari that when people asked the Prophet about meat when they didn't know if Allah's name was mentioned, he said 'Say the name of Allah yourselves then eat.' This was said about people new in Islam who weren't sure if they said Allah's name when slaughtering.

questionText: What is the ruling on selling one's hair according to the unanimous agreement of fuqaha'?

options.text: It is prohibited because hair is part of the person and the human being is honoured by Allah—selling it exposes one to disrespect
It is permissible if the buyer will use it for a wig
It is permissible if the proceeds are given to charity
It is permissible for women but not for men

explanation: The fuqaha' are unanimously agreed it is not permissible to benefit from human hair by selling it and using it, because the human being is honoured by Allah. Selling any part of one's body exposes one to disrespect and humiliation (al-Mawsoo'ah al-Fiqhiyyah 26/102).

questionText: If the sisters in the mosque cannot see the imam and the intercom system fails, what should they do?

options.text: Make intention to pray alone independently of the imam and complete the prayer on their own
Continue following the imam by estimating when he is making movements
Leave the mosque and pray at home
Wait until the system is fixed before continuing the prayer

explanation: If the sisters cannot see the imam or anyone behind him, and the intercom fails, each should make intention to pray alone independently of the imam and complete the prayer on her own. If someone can see/hear the imam and convey the takbeer, then they can continue following him.

questionText: What condition must be met for traditional councils to resolve conflicts and disputes in an acceptable manner?

options.text: The one passing judgement must have knowledge of shari'ah and judge according to what Allah revealed, not customs or whims
The council must include at least five elders from the community
All parties must be from the same tribe or family
The judgement must be approved by a government court afterward

explanation: There is nothing wrong with referring to traditional councils to resolve conflicts, so long as the one passing judgement has knowledge of shari'ah so he can judge between people according to what Allah revealed, not according to whims, desires, traditions or customs, many of which go against Allah's rulings.

questionText: What is the ruling on having a girlfriend according to the Quran, Sunnah, and scholarly consensus?

options.text: It is haram—Allah commands believing men to lower their gaze and guard their private parts
It is permissible if no physical contact occurs
It is makruh but not completely forbidden
It is permissible if the intention is to marry her

explanation: Having a girlfriend is haram according to the Quran, Sunnah, and scholarly consensus, even if no indecent actions are committed. Allah says 'Tell the believing men to lower their gaze and guard their private parts. That is purer for them' (an-Noor 24:30).

questionText: What is the ruling on wearing niqab (face veil) in Islam according to the evidence?

options.text: It is obligatory for women to cover their faces based on evidence from Quran and Sunnah
It is recommended but not obligatory
It is a cultural practice with no basis in Islam
It is only required during Hajj and Umrah

explanation: The evidence from Quran and Sunnah indicates that it is obligatory for women to cover their faces. This is the view of the majority of scholars based on verses like the command to draw veils over their bosoms and the distinction between elderly women.

questionText: When combining prayers due to travel, can the two prayers be separated by a significant time gap?

options.text: No, they should be prayed one immediately after the other, as was the practice of the Prophet
Yes, they can be separated by up to two hours
Yes, as long as both are prayed during the time of the first prayer
The gap doesn't matter as long as both are prayed before sunset

explanation: When combining prayers, they should be prayed one immediately after the other, following the Prophet's practice. Scholars like Ibn Taymiyah emphasized that combining means performing them together, not merely within the same time period.

questionText: Can someone in ihram for Hajj or Umrah remove their body hair even if it is harming them?

options.text: No, removing hair while in ihram is forbidden and requires offering a fidyah (sheep, fasting 3 days, or feeding 6 poor people)
Yes, if the hair is causing actual harm, no fidyah is required
Only head hair is forbidden; body hair can be removed
Removing hair invalidates the entire Hajj or Umrah

explanation: It is forbidden to remove hair while in ihram, whether head hair or body hair. If done, one must offer fidyah: slaughter a sheep, fast three days, or feed six poor people. This is based on the verse about shaving the head and the Prophet's instruction to Ka'b ibn 'Ujrah.

questionText: What is the Islamic ruling on a Muslim woman marrying a non-Muslim man?

options.text: It is unanimously agreed upon as haram—such a marriage is invalid and considered fornication
It is permissible if he is from the People of the Book (Christian or Jew)
It is permissible with the guardian's permission
It is makruh but the marriage is valid

explanation: It is unanimously agreed among Muslims that it is haram for a Muslim woman to marry a non-Muslim man, whether he is Jewish, Christian, or anything else. Such a marriage is invalid and is regarded as fornication, not marriage.

questionText: If someone prays without knowing the qiblah direction and later discovers they were wrong, what must they do?

options.text: If they made a sincere effort to determine the direction, their prayer is valid and doesn't need to be repeated
They must repeat all prayers performed in the wrong direction
The prayer is invalid only if they were more than 90 degrees off
They must repeat the prayer and fast one day as expiation

explanation: If a person strives to determine the qiblah direction using available evidence and prays, then later discovers he was mistaken, his prayer is valid according to the more correct scholarly opinion. This is based on Allah's command to fear Him as much as you can.

questionText: What is the minimum number of people required to establish a Friday (Jumu'ah) prayer?

options.text: The more correct view is that three people are sufficient—an imam and two others
At least forty men are required to make Jumu'ah valid
A minimum of twelve people including the imam
Seven people are needed based on the number of days in a week

explanation: The more correct scholarly view is that three people are sufficient for Jumu'ah—an imam and two others. This is based on the general evidence commanding Jumu'ah prayer without specifying a minimum number, and the hadith about congregation being established with two or more.

questionText: Is saying 'Jumu'ah Mubarakah' (Blessed Friday) or similar greetings an innovation in Islam?

options.text: It is an innovation with no basis in Sunnah—Friday should not be singled out for greetings not narrated from the Prophet
It is a good innovation that brings blessings
It is recommended based on the virtue of Friday
It is permissible as a cultural practice

explanation: Saying 'Jumu'ah Mubarakah' or 'Blessed Friday' is an innovation with no basis in the Sunnah. The Prophet and Sahabah did not single out Friday for such greetings. Muslims should not introduce practices in worship that were not prescribed.

questionText: Can a person make up missed Sunnah prayers along with the obligatory prayer?

options.text: No, only the obligatory prayer should be made up—Sunnah prayers that have been missed should not be made up
Yes, both the obligatory and Sunnah prayers should be made up together
Only the Sunnah of Fajr should be made up, not other Sunnah prayers
Sunnah prayers should be made up but after the obligatory prayer, not with it

explanation: When making up obligatory prayers, one should not make up the Sunnah prayers that were missed. The Sunnah is only to make up the obligatory prayer. However, the Sunnah of Fajr specifically may be made up after sunrise according to some scholars.

questionText: What is the ruling on accepting a gift from someone whose wealth is haram?

options.text: If some of their wealth is halal and some is haram, accepting gifts is permissible but better to avoid if most is haram
All gifts from such a person are completely forbidden
Gifts are permissible as long as you purify them by giving charity
Only food gifts are forbidden; money gifts are permissible

explanation: If someone's wealth includes both halal and haram sources, accepting gifts is permissible according to the more correct view, as the origin is that wealth is halal. However, it is better to avoid if most of their wealth is haram. If all their wealth is haram, accepting gifts is forbidden.

questionText: Should one wipe the entire head during wudu or is it sufficient to wipe part of it?

options.text: Wiping the entire head is obligatory according to the more correct view, from the hairline to the nape and including the sides
Wiping any part of the head, even a small portion, is sufficient
Only the front half of the head needs to be wiped
Just wiping the top of the head from front to back is enough

explanation: The more correct scholarly view is that it is obligatory to wipe the entire head during wudu, from the front hairline to the nape of the neck, and the sides too. This is based on the verse 'wipe over your heads' and the Prophet's practice.

questionText: What is the ruling on delaying ghusl from janaabah (major impurity) until after Fajr time begins during Ramadan?

options.text: The fast is valid—one can delay ghusl until after Fajr, as proven by Aishah about the Prophet's practice
The fast is invalid and must be made up
Delaying ghusl is permissible for women but not for men
The fast is valid but one must give fidyah

explanation: The fast is valid even if one delays ghusl until after Fajr. Aishah narrated that the Prophet would sometimes wake up in a state of janaabah from his wife (not a dream) in Ramadan, then do ghusl and fast. This proves delaying ghusl doesn't affect the fast.

questionText: If someone forgets to recite Fatihah in one or more rak'ahs of prayer, what is the ruling?

options.text: That rak'ah is invalid and must be made up—add a rak'ah at the end and perform sujood sahw after salaam
The entire prayer is invalid and must be repeated from the beginning
Sujood sahw before salaam is sufficient to correct the mistake
The prayer is valid without any correction needed

explanation: Reciting al-Fatihah is a pillar (rukn) of prayer. If omitted in a rak'ah, that rak'ah doesn't count. One must make up the missed rak'ah by adding one at the end, then perform sujood sahw after giving salaam, based on the Prophet's instruction in the hadith.

questionText: What is the ruling on using henna that contains impure ingredients like urine?

options.text: It is forbidden to use if it contains impure substances, as this brings impurity to the body and prevents wudu water from reaching skin
It is permissible because the impure ingredient becomes transformed
It is permissible if the amount of impurity is very small
It is permissible as long as you wash it off before prayer

explanation: It is not permissible to use henna containing impure ingredients like urine. This brings impurity to the body and may form a layer preventing water from reaching the skin during wudu and ghusl. One should avoid such products even if commonly used.

questionText: Is it permissible to delay Isha prayer until the last third of the night or later?

options.text: It is permissible if not too difficult, and the Prophet said 'If it were not too hard for my ummah, I would have commanded them to delay it'
It is forbidden to delay Isha beyond the first third of the night
Isha must be prayed immediately after Maghrib ends
Delaying Isha is only permissible when traveling

explanation: The Prophet said 'If it were not too hard for my ummah, I would have commanded them to delay Isha prayer until halfway through the night or the last third of the night.' This indicates it is permissible and even preferred to delay Isha if it's not too difficult.

questionText: What is the ruling on performing Umrah on behalf of someone who is still alive but unable to do it themselves?

options.text: It is permissible if the person is unable due to chronic illness or old age and has no hope of recovery
It is not permissible under any circumstances—only deceased people can have Umrah done on their behalf
It is permissible for parents only, not other relatives
It is permissible only if the person gives written permission

explanation: It is permissible to perform Umrah on behalf of someone alive who is unable to do it due to chronic illness or old age with no hope of recovery. This is based on the hadith of the woman whose father was obliged to perform Hajj but was unable.

questionText: What is the Islamic ruling on celebrating the Prophet's birthday (Mawlid)?

options.text: It is a reprehensible innovation that was not done by the Prophet, his Sahabah, or the righteous predecessors
It is a good innovation that shows love for the Prophet
It is permissible as long as no haram acts are involved
It is recommended based on celebrating the Prophet's life

explanation: Celebrating Mawlid is a reprehensible innovation in religion. It was not done by the Prophet, the Sahabah, or the righteous predecessors. All innovations in religion are misguidance, as the Prophet said 'Every innovation is a going astray.'

questionText: Can women attend Eid prayer in the mosque according to Islamic teaching?

options.text: Yes, it is Sunnah for them to attend, including menstruating women who should avoid the prayer area but witness the gathering
No, women should pray Eid at home
Only elderly women are permitted to attend
Women can attend only if there is a separate mosque for them

explanation: It is Sunnah for women to attend Eid prayer. The Prophet commanded that all women, even menstruating ones, go out to the Eid prayer. Menstruating women should keep away from the prayer area but witness the Muslims' gathering and supplication, as narrated in Sahih Bukhari and Muslim.

questionText: What is the ruling on saying 'Jumu'ah taqabbal Allah' (May Allah accept your Friday) or similar phrases?

options.text: It is an innovation if done regularly as a Friday greeting, as this was not the practice of the Prophet or Sahabah
It is recommended since it includes a good supplication
It is obligatory to greet Muslims this way on Friday
It is permissible and has basis in Sunnah

explanation: Regularly saying such phrases as a Friday-specific greeting is an innovation, as this was not the practice of the Prophet or his Sahabah. While general duas for Muslims are good, singling out Friday for specific greetings that weren't prescribed is not from the Sunnah.

questionText: Should one make up prayers missed during menstruation or postnatal bleeding?

options.text: No, women do not have to make up prayers missed during menstruation or postnatal bleeding according to scholarly consensus
Yes, all missed prayers must be made up after becoming pure
Only Fajr and Maghrib prayers need to be made up
The prayers should be made up only if the period lasted more than seven days

explanation: Women do not have to make up prayers missed during menstruation or postnatal bleeding. This is agreed upon by scholarly consensus. Aishah said: 'We were commanded to make up fasts but were not commanded to make up prayers' (Bukhari and Muslim).

questionText: What is the minimum distance that defines travel (safar) for purposes of shortening prayers and breaking fast?

options.text: There is no specific distance in Quran or Sunnah—it is whatever people customarily call travel in their language
Exactly 83 kilometers or approximately 50 miles
A journey of at least three days on foot
48 miles or approximately 77 kilometers

explanation: The more correct scholarly view (Ibn Taymiyah, Ibn Hazm) is that there is no specific distance that defines travel in shari'ah. Rather, it is whatever people customarily regard as travel in their language and culture. Allah commanded travelers to shorten prayers without specifying a distance.

questionText: Can men wear gold-plated watches or accessories in Islam?

options.text: It is haram for men to wear gold-plated items because the prohibition applies even to small amounts of gold
It is permissible if the gold layer is very thin
Only pure gold is forbidden; plated gold is permissible
It is makruh but not haram

explanation: It is haram for men to wear gold-plated items. The prohibition on gold for men includes all gold, even small amounts. The Prophet forbade men from wearing gold, and this applies to pure gold and gold-plating alike.

questionText: What is the ruling on insurance in Islam?

options.text: Commercial insurance is haram based on resolutions of Islamic Fiqh councils because it involves riba, gharar, and gambling
All types of insurance are permissible as they protect against harm
Only life insurance is haram; other types are permissible
Insurance is permissible if the company is Islamic

explanation: Commercial insurance is haram according to resolutions of Islamic Fiqh councils. It involves riba (interest), gharar (uncertainty), and gambling elements. However, cooperative insurance that avoids these elements is permissible.

questionText: Is it permissible to make du'a in languages other than Arabic during prayer?

options.text: In obligatory prayers, one should only make du'a with what is narrated in Arabic; in naafil prayers, other languages are permissible according to some scholars
Any language is permissible in all prayers
Only Arabic is permissible in all prayers without exception
Non-Arabic du'a is permissible only for those who don't know Arabic

explanation: In obligatory prayers, one should limit du'a to what is narrated in Arabic from the Prophet. In naafil prayers, using other languages for du'a is permissible according to some scholars, though Arabic is better. This is the view of Ibn Taymiyah and others.

questionText: What is the ruling on looking at the 'awrah (private parts) of one's spouse?

options.text: It is permissible—each spouse may look at and touch all parts of the other's body
It is makruh though not forbidden
It is only permissible in darkness, not in light
Looking is permissible but touching is not

explanation: It is permissible for each spouse to look at and touch all parts of the other's body. Allah says 'And those who guard their chastity except from their wives' (al-Mu'minoon 23:5-6). This indicates that everything is permitted between spouses.

questionText: Is it required to have a specific number of witnesses present at the time of consummating the marriage?

options.text: No witnesses are required at consummation—witnesses are only required for the marriage contract itself
Two witnesses must be present when consummating the marriage
The wali (guardian) must be present during consummation
At least one witness should be nearby during consummation

explanation: Witnesses are only required for the marriage contract, not for the consummation. Once a valid contract is done with witnesses, the couple may be alone together and consummate the marriage without any witnesses being present.

questionText: Can a person in a state of major impurity (janaabah) recite Quran from memory?

options.text: It is not permissible to recite Quran in a state of janaabah until after performing ghusl, according to the more correct view
It is permissible to recite from memory but not from the Mushaf
It is permissible without any restrictions
Only short surahs (less than 5 verses) may be recited

explanation: According to the more correct scholarly view, a person in janaabah should not recite Quran at all, whether from memory or from Mushaf, until after ghusl. The Prophet would not recite Quran when in a state of janaabah, as narrated by Ali.

questionText: What is the ruling on working as a cashier where one may have to sell alcohol or pork?

options.text: It is haram—the Prophet cursed alcohol, the one who drinks it, sells it, and others involved in its trade
It is permissible if you are only the cashier and not the seller
It is permissible if you donate the earnings from those sales
It is makruh but the income is halal

explanation: It is haram to work as a cashier where you sell alcohol or pork. The Prophet cursed alcohol, the one who drinks it, the one who pours it, the one who sells it, and others involved. This applies to pork as well. One must find alternative halal employment.

questionText: Can a menstruating woman enter the mosque if she needs to?

options.text: The more correct view is that she can enter if needed, but it is better to avoid lingering without need
It is absolutely forbidden for a menstruating woman to enter the mosque
She can enter only the entrance area, not the main prayer hall
She can enter only if wearing a face veil

explanation: The more correct view is that a menstruating woman can enter the mosque if needed, as there is no clear authentic evidence forbidding it. However, it is better for her to avoid staying in the mosque without need. This is the view of scholars like Ibn Taymiyah.

questionText: Is it permissible to use pictures and videos for educational purposes in Islamic teaching?

options.text: It is not permissible except in cases of necessity, as the prohibition on images includes educational use
It is permissible for educational purposes without restriction
It is permissible if the images are of scholars or historical figures
Modern images and videos are not included in the prohibition

explanation: The prohibition on image-making applies generally and is not lifted for educational purposes except in cases of genuine necessity. Alternatives like blackboards and diagrams should be used. This is the position of many contemporary scholars based on hadith evidence.

questionText: What is the status of saying 'Bismillah' before eating according to Islamic teaching?

options.text: It is obligatory—the Prophet commanded saying Allah's name before eating and drinking
It is Sunnah but not obligatory
It is recommended only for main meals, not snacks
It is only required when eating meat

explanation: Saying 'Bismillah' before eating is obligatory according to the more correct view. The Prophet commanded 'When any of you eats, let him mention the name of Allah.' Commands indicate obligation unless there is evidence otherwise. This is the view of Ibn Hazm and others.

questionText: Can women wear trousers in front of other women or mahrams?

options.text: It is permissible if the trousers are wide and loose and do not show the shape of the body
It is completely forbidden for women to wear trousers
Women can only wear trousers under a long garment
Trousers are permissible only when doing housework

explanation: Women can wear trousers in front of other women or mahrams if the trousers are wide, loose, and do not show the shape of the body or legs. Tight trousers that reveal the shape are not permissible even in front of other women.

questionText: What is the minimum age at which a child can be rewarded for prayer?

options.text: A child can be rewarded for prayer from the time they can distinguish and understand, even before age seven
Only from age seven when they should be commanded to pray
Only from age ten when they can be disciplined for not praying
Only after reaching puberty when prayer becomes obligatory

explanation: A child can be rewarded for prayer from when they can distinguish and understand, even before age seven. They have the ability to do righteous deeds and be rewarded. The command to teach them at seven is to train them, but reward can come earlier if they pray with understanding.

questionText: Can a Muslim greet a non-Muslim first by saying 'As-salaamu alaykum'?

options.text: No, Muslims should not initiate greetings to non-Muslims, as the Prophet said 'Do not initiate the greeting'
Yes, it is recommended to promote good relations
Yes, but only with People of the Book
It is permissible if they are neighbors or coworkers

explanation: Muslims should not initiate greetings of salaam to non-Muslims. The Prophet said 'Do not initiate the greeting to the Jews and Christians.' If greeted, reply with 'wa alaykum' (and upon you). However, Muslims can greet with words other than salaam if needed.

questionText: Is it permissible to use credit cards that charge annual fees or service charges?

options.text: Fixed annual fees are permissible if they are for actual services, not interest-based or percentage-based fees
All fees on credit cards are riba and therefore forbidden
Fees are only permissible on Islamic credit cards
Annual fees are permissible but service charges are not

explanation: Fixed annual fees for actual services (like card issuance, processing) are permissible as they are payment for services rendered. However, interest-based fees, late payment penalties, or percentage-based charges that exceed actual costs are not permissible as they constitute riba.

questionText: If someone buys something and finds a defect after leaving the shop, can they return it?

options.text: Yes, the buyer has the option to return it or keep it with a price reduction if there is a defect
No, once the buyer leaves the shop, the sale is final
Returns are only possible if agreed upon before purchase
The seller can refuse returns if the defect is minor

explanation: If the buyer finds a defect after purchase, they have the option to return the item or keep it with a reduction in price. The seller is obliged to accept the return or provide compensation, as this is part of justice in transactions mandated in Islam.

questionText: Can someone perform Hajj using money earned through haram means?

options.text: The Hajj is valid but sinful, and the person must repent and get rid of the haram wealth
The Hajj is completely invalid and doesn't fulfill the obligation
The Hajj is valid only if the person makes tawbah first
The person must repeat Hajj with halal wealth for it to be accepted

explanation: The Hajj performed with haram wealth is valid and fulfills the obligation, but the person is sinful for using haram wealth. The person must repent, dispose of the haram wealth properly, and seek Allah's forgiveness. This is the view of the majority of scholars.

questionText: What is the ruling on women removing facial hair?

options.text: It is permissible to remove abnormal facial hair like a beard or mustache, but not to remove fine natural hair for beautification
It is completely forbidden to remove any facial hair
All facial hair removal is permissible for women
Only threading is forbidden; other methods are permissible

explanation: It is permissible for women to remove abnormal facial hair like a beard or mustache that is unusual for women. However, removing the fine natural hair on the face for beautification is not permissible as it may fall under the prohibited category of changing Allah's creation.

questionText: Is it obligatory to remove pubic hair and armpit hair in Islam?

options.text: Yes, it is part of the fitrah and should not be left for more than forty days according to hadith
It is recommended but not obligatory
It is only obligatory before going for Hajj or Umrah
It is obligatory only for those who can afford hair removal services

explanation: Removing pubic and armpit hair is part of the fitrah (natural disposition) and is obligatory. Anas narrated that a time limit was set for them not to leave these matters for more than forty days. This includes trimming the mustache, cutting nails, and plucking armpit hair.

questionText: What is the ruling on a woman traveling for Hajj without a mahram?

options.text: It is not permissible—the Prophet forbade women from traveling without a mahram, and Hajj is not obligatory on her in this case
It is permissible if she travels with a group of trustworthy women
It is permissible because Hajj is obligatory
It is permissible only for women over 45 years old

explanation: It is not permissible for a woman to travel for Hajj without a mahram. The Prophet said 'A woman should not travel except with a mahram.' If she has no mahram, Hajj is not obligatory upon her. The obligation of having a mahram cannot be overridden.

questionText: Can Muslims celebrate secular holidays like New Year or national days?

options.text: It is not permissible to celebrate any holidays except the two Eids and Fridays, as the Prophet said 'Allah has given you something better than them'
Secular holidays are permissible since they are not religious
National days are permissible but not religious holidays of other faiths
It is permissible to participate for social reasons without celebrating

explanation: Muslims should not celebrate any holidays except Eid al-Fitr, Eid al-Adha, and Fridays. When the Prophet came to Madinah and found people celebrating two days, he said 'Allah has given you something better than them: Eid al-Adha and Eid al-Fitr.' This indicates these are the only holidays for Muslims.

questionText: Is music and musical instruments permissible in Islam?

options.text: They are haram according to evidence from Quran, Sunnah, and scholarly consensus, except the daff on specific occasions
All music and instruments are permissible in Islam
Only certain types of music are haram
Music is permissible if the lyrics are Islamic

explanation: Musical instruments are haram according to evidence from Quran, Sunnah, and consensus of four madhahib. The Prophet said those who listen to music will have molten lead poured into their ears on Judgment Day. The exception is the daff (hand drum) for women on Eids and weddings.

questionText: Can Muslims say 'Christmas Mubarak' or congratulate non-Muslims on their holidays?

options.text: It is haram—congratulating them on their festivals is approval of their disbelief, which is worse than other sins
It is permissible as a way of showing good manners
It is permissible if you don't celebrate with them
It is permissible for coworkers and neighbors only

explanation: It is haram to congratulate non-Muslims on their religious festivals. Ibn al-Qayyim said this is haram according to consensus, as it implies approval of their disbelief in Allah. This is worse than congratulating them for drinking wine or murder, as it relates to disbelief in Allah.

questionText: What happens to the soul immediately after death according to Islamic belief?

options.text: The soul of a believer is taken up to the seventh heaven where Allah commands it be recorded in Illiyyeen, then returned to the grave
The soul remains in the body until the Day of Resurrection
The soul immediately enters Paradise or Hell
The soul wanders the earth for forty days before going to the grave

explanation: According to the hadith of al-Bara' ibn 'Aazib, when a believer dies, angels take the soul up through the heavens to the seventh heaven, where Allah commands it be recorded in 'Illiyyeen. Then it is returned to the earth to the grave where it is questioned. The disbeliever's soul is taken down to Sijjeen.

questionText: According to Ibn al-Qayyim, in how many different ways is the soul connected to the body?

options.text: Five different ways, each with different rules that apply to them
Three ways: as a foetus, during waking life, and in al-Barzakh
Two primary ways: complete connection during life and partial separation after death
Seven stages from conception through resurrection, corresponding to seven levels of creation

explanation: Ibn al-Qayyim explained that the soul is connected to the body in five different ways with different rules: (1) as a foetus in the mother's womb, (2) after birth, (3) during sleep when partially separated, (4) in al-Barzakh when returned for salaam greetings, and (5) on the Day of Resurrection with the most perfect connection.

questionText: According to the hadith in Ahmad from Abd-Allah ibn Amr, what specific reason will the Quran give when interceding on the Day of Resurrection?

options.text: I deprived him of his sleep at night, so let me intercede for him
I was his companion in times of ease and hardship, so let me intercede for him
I protected him from negligence and heedlessness, so let me intercede for him
I was upon his tongue in all his prayers, so let me intercede for him

explanation: The hadith states that fasting and the Quran will both intercede. Fasting will say 'I deprived him of his food and desires during the day', while the Quran will say 'I deprived him of his sleep at night'. This hadith was narrated by Ahmad and classed as sahih by al-Albani.

questionText: How does Islam explain apparent differences between prophets' teachings on fighting, such as between Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad (peace be upon them)?

options.text: All prophets shared the same core beliefs (Tawheed), but Allah prescribed different detailed laws and juristic rulings for each nation
All prophets originally taught identical rules on fighting, but the Torah and Gospel were later corrupted by their followers
Fighting was progressively introduced - prohibited for Jesus, permitted for Moses, and made central for Muhammad
The differences reflect each prophet's personal circumstances and enemies, not divine prescription

explanation: The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said prophets are like half-brothers with different mothers but one religion - their core beliefs (Tawheed) are identical, while Allah prescribed different laws for different nations. Allah says: 'To each among you, We have prescribed a law and a clear way' [al-Ma'idah 5:48]. Even within Islam, fighting was not prescribed in Makkah but was permitted after migration to Madinah.
tags: Striving and migrating for the sake of Allaah

questionText: According to the Prophet's instruction to Mu'ath ibn Jabal when sending him to Yemen, what should be the first thing to call people to?

options.text: To testify that there is no God but Allah, and Muhammad is His Messenger
To establish the five daily prayers at their proper times
To fulfill the obligation of Zakat from the rich to the poor
To wisdom, peaceful advice and flexibility in their approach

explanation: The Prophet (peace be upon him) instructed Mu'ath with a clear sequence: First call them to testify (Shahadah). If they respond, then ask them to pray. If they respond to that, then tell them about Zakat. This shows the priority is establishing Tawheed (Oneness of Allah) as the foundation before other obligations.

questionText: What do all the fuqaha' unanimously agree is one of the pillars (rukn) of fasting?

options.text: Abstaining from things that break the fast from true dawn until sunset
The intention (niyyah), though they differ on whether it's a pillar or condition
Both abstinence and intention together, with no scholarly disagreement
Abstaining from food, drink and sexual relations specifically (the three main invalidators)

explanation: The fuqaha' are all agreed that abstaining from things that break the fast from true dawn until sunset is a pillar. However, they differed on intention: Hanafis and Hanbalis view it as a condition, while Malikis and Shafi'is view it as a pillar. Regardless, both abstinence and intention are essential for a valid fast.

questionText: If a boss with proper authority allows an employee to work only 4 hours but record 8 hours because there's insufficient work, what did Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymeen rule?

options.text: If the work doesn't need them present and the boss with authority permits it, there is nothing wrong with it
Even with the boss's permission, the employee must refuse and work full hours to earn their salary legitimately
It is permissible only if the employee donates the salary for the unworked hours to charity
The immediate boss can give permission, but the employee should consult higher management to be safe

explanation: Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymeen stated that if the work does not require the employee's presence and the immediate boss (who has authority over work hours) gives permission, there is nothing wrong with this arrangement. The key factors are: (1) proper authority approves it, and (2) the work genuinely doesn't need them present.

questionText: What is the Islamic ruling on mediating in the sale of a tourist village where alcohol will be served and other prohibited activities will take place?

options.text: Not permissible, as it is helping in sin and transgression, and the intermediary bears a burden like those who follow without diminishing theirs
Permissible if the mediator only facilitates the sale transaction without being involved in village operations
Permissible if the mediator privately denounces these evils and donates part of the commission to charity
Permissible because the village will also serve halal food and may host some Muslim tourists

explanation: Mediating in such a sale is helping in sin and transgression, which is forbidden. Allah says: 'Help one another in virtue and righteousness, but do not help one another in sin and transgression' [al-Ma'idah 5:2]. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said whoever calls to misguidance bears a burden like those who follow without diminishing their burdens (Muslim, 4831). A Muslim should denounce such establishments, not help establish them.

questionText: If a grandfather made a will depriving females of inheritance, does this will affect how his son's (the grandchildren's father's) estate must be divided?

options.text: No, the grandfather's will only affects his own estate; the father's estate must be divided according to Shariah giving females their mandated shares
Yes, the grandfather's will creates a family precedent that should be honored for subsequent generations
It depends on whether the father explicitly rejected or accepted the grandfather's approach before his death
The family can vote to decide whether to follow the grandfather's will or Islamic inheritance law

explanation: The grandfather's unjust will (which contradicts Allah's ordained inheritance divisions) only applies to his own estate and has no effect on his son's estate. Each person's estate must be divided according to Islamic inheritance law as ordained by Allah, which mandates specific shares for males and females. Allah warns against transgressing these limits in Surah al-Nisa.
tags: Inheritance and distribution of the estate

questionText: Are the isti'aadhah (seeking refuge from Shaytan) and basmalah (Bismillah) part of the opening du'aa' that the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to recite?

options.text: No, they are not part of the opening du'aa', though they should be recited at the beginning of prayer
Yes, Aishah reported the Prophet would open prayer with isti'aadhah, basmalah, then the opening du'aa'
The basmalah is part of it, but the isti'aadhah should only be said before reciting al-Fatihah
They are part of it when praying alone, but not when following an imam

explanation: The isti'aadhah and basmalah are not part of the opening du'aa' reported from the Prophet (peace be upon him). Aishah (may Allah be pleased with her) said the Messenger of Allah used to open his prayer with takbeer (Allahu akbar), as reported by Muslim (498). While they should be recited at the start of prayer, they are separate from the opening supplication.

questionText: What is the ruling on a fasting person receiving injections during Ramadan daytime for medical purposes (not nourishment)?
